audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a mellow, slow-tempo instrumental tune played on a piano, creating a relaxed atmosphere. Then, a male speaker starts talking in a casual tone, introducing the topic of addressing an Apple Mac flashing a folder with a question mark. He explains it indicates the startup disk is unavailable, either from a failed hard drive or a broken connection cable. The speaker shares his experiences with other unsuccessful online remedies, offering to share his solution. Finally, he proposes stepping through possible solutions.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker advising listeners to adjust their computer screen brightness, ensuring their Mac is on before diving into serious troubleshooting. He suggests resetting the "temporary non-volatile RAM", explaining its role in speaker volume and startup data, and outlining the specific button sequence and method to accomplish this reset. Afterwards, speech ceases.

The audio begins with a male speaker expressing disappointment that something hasn't worked for him, and he is facing the "gray flashing folder" issue. He then switches to a more instructional tone, suggesting the Mac might be booting from the wrong drive. He gives instructions, starting with how to turn off the Mac by holding the power button, then explains how to restart while holding the option button to access different drives. He references the option of "Macintosh HD" and suggests allowing the computer to boot from the selected drive, expressing hope that it will work.

The audio clip starts with a single speaker, a man, who states, "myself, unfortunately, it didn't." He then announces the intention to proceed to the next step. The next phase involves attempting to repair the disk via recovery mode and disk utilities. He instructs to turn off the Mac by holding down the power button, then turn it back on while pressing and holding the command plus the R key, and pressing the power button. He specifies releasing the keys upon hearing the Apple chime or seeing the Apple logo. The speaker then notes you may need to enter your administrator or Wi-Fi password.

A male speaker begins in a hopeful tone, mentioning steps that might have worked. His tone shifts to reflecting on personal experience, noting difficulty accessing a specific screen. The speaker details using an external hard drive with a Time Machine backup. The speaker's tone shifts to describing how to press and hold commands to enter recovery mode, mentioning entering a Wi-Fi password. The speech is followed by music playing in the background.

The audio starts with a male speaker explaining a process within "disk utilities," pointing out elements such as the "time machine" and external hard drives. His tone is instructional and calm. He notes the absence of an internal hard drive listing, suggesting how to reveal it. He goes on to advise on using the "first aid" option to repair the drive, suggesting a Mac restart.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker expressing frustration that his hard disk isn't showing, meaning he can't repair it. He speaks with a slightly resigned tone, then transitions to a suggestion: "so let's move on to the final". The audio cuts off abruptly before he can finish his sentence.

The audio clip begins with speech from a single male speaker, discussing recovering mode and connecting to the Internet, then transitioning to installing a Mac operating system on a new external hard drive, or reformatting an old drive at the risk of data loss.
He then instructs the listener to click on the external hard drive, access the "erase option", name the drive, and specify the format as "Mac OS extended" with GUID partition map.
He stresses that clicking "erase" will eliminate all data from the drive, reinforcing his previous warnings.

The clip starts with a male speaker explaining that they've finished a task and can "quit disk utilities and get back to the main recovery screen," advising to hit the "X" or "go to file and quit disk utilities." He then notes they are back in recovery mode and suggests clicking "reinstall Mac OS and reinstall a new copy of the operating system" onto the "new bootable drive." The speaker's tone is instructional and calm.

The clip starts with a male speaker stating "Unfortunately, I didn't record this section very well." He then says, it will take some time to reinstall the Mac operating system depending on internet speed. After the installation, Apple will give the option to migrate information from an old Mac or Time Machine, using his Time Machine. The same male speaker notes that his computer is working as fast as before when using the high-speed external SanDisk drive and offers a link to Amazon.

A male speaker begins by expressing frustration over the use of USB ports by an external hard drive connected to a 2003 iMac. He contemplates replacing the physical drive and mentions an estimated cost from a store. He then shifts to sharing another important point about navigating to system preferences and startup disk to ensure the operating system is running on the correct drive, emphasizing the necessity of selecting the right disk after reformatting. This ensures the computer knows which drive to use upon restart.

The audio clip features a single male speaker with a conversational tone, first expressing hope that the listener enjoyed the video and urging them to "like and subscribe." He then hopes it has "fixed the problem for yourself."  He asks listeners to leave a comment if they have more questions, and ends by wishing them "all the best with your computer."
